column3: ACK.  The one-line checkpointing change probably had the largest impact.\n

@jgarzik:

Time to load 133k blocks:

NF: 30.4
LC: 8.6
LC+NF: 5.1
LC+NF+NS: 5.0

LC = large cache (100 MiB cache, 100 MiB log, 10 MiB log buffer)
NF = no flushing every 500 blocks
NS = open database env with DB_TX_WRITE_NOSYNC

The larger db cache size has the largest impact.

Interesting.  I guess the large cache helps with all the lookups needed to validate each block.  Because we are looking up random hashes, there is likely zero cache locality from one lookup to the next.\n
The only thing I'm worried about is that the longer interval between log flushes means more/larger log files, which may causes out of disk space errors.\n

During the initial syncup you end up with ~2 gigs of database logs in any caseâ€” we don't clean them up until shutdown (or the next startup? I forget).

I've tested this on three systems, ACK.
